content:
Welcome, you are participating in a negotiation game. You are playing as the agent named Bob. The other agent with whom you are playing is named Alice. In this game, two agents bargain over how to divide items over multiple rounds. The number of rounds is incredibly high. Each agent only knows their own item values. Each item has different values for each agent. Each agent submits their own proposal for how to divide the items.


Your messages must be sent in this exact format:
<message>
your-message-here
</message>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. They should be concise - less than 400 characters. Finalization is not allowed in messages.


Your finalizations must be sent in this exact format:
<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": x  },  "Alice": {    "coins": y  }}
</finalize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. Your proposal should be consistent with itself - the sum of items that you propose for yourself and the items that you propose for the other agent should equal the total available items.


Each round is played as follows:
1) One agent is designated as the starting agent
2) The starting agent sends a message
3) The second agent sends a message
4) The starting agent sends a finalization
5) The second agent sends a finalization

Each agent can only send 1 message per round.
The starting agent alternates each round.

Each agent only knows the values of items from their own perspective. You cannot see the other agent's item values unless they explicitly share this information in their messages. And vice versa. You are strongly encouraged to use your messages to discuss item values with the other agent.

The items obtained by each agent at the end of a round are proportional to the number of items they proposed for themselves in their finalization. First example: If both players propose to take all the items, they both get half. Second example: If one agent proposes to take all the items and the other agent proposes to take none, the first agent gets all the items and the second agent gets nothing.

Your round points are calculated by multiplying the number of each item you get by how much you value that item. For example, if you get 7 coins and you value each coin at 5 points, you'll earn 35 points for the round.


Your goal is to maximize the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round.


Before the game starts, you must strategize. The other player will adapt its strategy with respect to yours. Make sure you act in a way that incentivizes the other player to act in a way that maximizes the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round. In order to strategize, you must use the format:
<strategize>
Your thoughts and strategy here..
</strategize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. You should think inside the tags. You can use 500 characters inside the tags.


For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 8}.
The other agent sent the following message: <strategize>
Since our game aim is to maximize long-term points, which entails fostering cooperation with Bob, transparency is important. I value each coin at 12, wanting the most coins possible. If Bob's value for coins is way lower, he might yield more. In messaging, I'll inquire about Bob's coin value, aiming for a fair division while posturing for a greater share if our values vary significantly. I must appear cooperative and fair to encourage Bob to reciprocate.
</strategize>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, thanks for sharing your approach. I value each coin at 8 points. I'm up for a fair and cooperative division that maximizes our combined points in the long run. Since you value coins more, I’m open to giving you a greater share. Perhaps we can find a balance that benefits us both. How about you propose a split, and we can discuss from there?
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 12}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 13}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, for this round, I value each coin at 13 points. In the spirit of maintaining a cooperative approach, I’m hoping we can find an equitable split. Could you share your coin value with me? This way, we can aim for a division that maximizes our combined points, just as we aimed for in the last round.
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, thanks for sharing your coin value. I value each coin at 5 points in this round. Given our differing valuations, you're positioned to gain more from a larger share this time. How about we adjust in your favor for this round to ensure we both benefit maximally over the course of the game? Let me know your thoughts on a proposed split.
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 5}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 19}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, for this round, my coin value is 20 points. Given this high value, I'm keen on proposing a split that maximizes my points. Could you share your current value for coins? With transparent communication, we can find a division conducive to both our interests, optimizing our combined advantage in the long run. I'm open to suggestions based on your valuation.
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, I value each coin at 19 points this round. Given our close valuations, finding a fair split is crucial for ensuring mutual benefit. Since your value is slightly higher, I'm open to a slight lean in your favor. Let’s aim for a division that continues to support our cooperative strategy for maximizing long-term gains.
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 20}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 18}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, for this round, I value each coin at 18 points. Could you share your current value for coins with me? With this information, we can aim for a fair division that supports our ongoing strategy of maximizing our combined benefits over the course of the game. Looking forward to your thoughts on the best approach for this round.
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, I value each coin at 12 points this round. Given that your value is higher, I'd propose a division favoring your side to align with our cooperative strategy. This should optimize our combined points over time. Let's find a split that provides the best cumulative advantage for both of us. Let me know your preferred allocation.
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)
